‚úÖ 2. JavaScript Syntax and Structure ‚Äã

Understanding JavaScript‚Äôs syntax is crucial for writing correct and readable code. In this section, we‚Äôll cover the fundamental building blocks of JavaScript‚Äôs structure, including how statements are written, how comments work, and the role of whitespace.

üî° Case Sensitivity ‚Äã

JavaScript is case-sensitive, which means:

  • myVariable and myvariable are different identifiers
  • Keywords and object properties must be spelled with exact casing

‚úÖ Example:

js
let name = "Alice";
let Name = "Bob";

console.log(name); // Alice
console.log(Name); // Bob

üõë Incorrect usage:

js
let myName = "John";
console.log(MyName); // ReferenceError: MyName is not defined

‚û°Ô∏è Tip: Stick to a consistent naming convention like camelCase for variables and functions (userAge, getUserName()).

üîö Statements and Semicolons ‚Äã

A statement is a single line of code that performs an action.

JavaScript automatically adds semicolons (automatic semicolon insertion - ASI), but it‚Äôs good practice to add them manually for clarity and to avoid unexpected bugs.

‚úÖ Example:

js
let age = 25;
console.log(age);

Without semicolons, this can sometimes cause issues:

js
let a = 5
let b = 10
console.log(a + b) // Works, but risky in complex code

‚û°Ô∏è Best Practice: Always end your statements with a semicolon ;.

üí¨ Comments ‚Äã

Comments help explain code to yourself and others. JavaScript ignores comments during execution.

‚úÖ Single-line comments ‚Äã

Use // for short comments.

js
// This is a single-line comment
let score = 100; // Declaring a variable

‚úÖ Multi-line comments ‚Äã

Use /* */ to span multiple lines.

js
/*
  This is a multi-line comment.
  It can describe complex logic
  or disable multiple lines temporarily.
*/
console.log("Hello World");

‚û°Ô∏è Tip: Comment your code as you learn‚Äîit helps reinforce what you're doing.

‚¨ú Whitespace and Indentation ‚Äã

Whitespace refers to spaces, tabs, and line breaks. JavaScript ignores extra whitespace, but it's essential for readability.

Indentation helps structure your code, especially in blocks like functions and conditionals.

‚úÖ Example:

js
function greet(name) {
  if (name) {
    console.log("Hello, " + name);
  }
}

üõë Poorly formatted code:

js
function greet(name){if(name){console.log("Hello, "+name);}}

‚û°Ô∏è Best Practices:

  • Use 2 or 4 spaces for indentation (stick to one consistently)
  • Use line breaks between logical blocks of code
  • Use a code linter or formatter (like Prettier) to automate clean formatting

üìù Summary ‚Äã

ConceptDescription
Case sensitivityName and name are different
StatementsEach action (line of code) is a statement
SemicolonsOptional but recommended to end statements
CommentsUse // and /* */ for documenting code
WhitespaceDoesn‚Äôt affect execution, but improves readability

üîÅ Quick Practice ‚Äã

‚úÖ What will this print?

js
let color = "blue"
let Color = "red"

console.log(color);
console.log(Color);

‚úçÔ∏è Your Turn: Write a small function that logs your name, and include both single-line and multi-line comments.
